data.name: Counting E-Primes
data.description:
You may have heard that whole numbers have a nice property called unique factorization: every whole number greater than one can be written as a product of its prime factors. Moreover, ignoring any reordering of the prime factors, this decomposition is unique. For example:

12 = 2 × 2 × 3,

16 = 2 × 2 × 2 × 2, 

17 = 17

115,236 = 2 × 2 × 3 × 3 × 3 × 11 × 97,

and so on. In fact, this result is so beloved that it has been dubbed the [Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fundamental_theorem_of_arithmetic). To really appreciate this result, it may help to consider an example of a set of numbers for which unique factorization fails.

Here's a relatively simple example: consider the set of even numbers { 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, ... }. A number in this set is called an _e-prime_ if it can't be written as a product of other even numbers. For example, 2 is an _e-prime_ (since it's prime), but 4 is not, since 4 = 2 * 2. 

The first interesting case is 6. 6 is an _e-prime_. Even though 6 = 2 × 3, 3 is not in the set of even numbers. Since 6 can't be written as a product of even numbers, it must be an _e-prime_.

Unlike the set of whole numbers, which have unique factorization into primes, even numbers *do not have* unique factorization into e-primes. For instance, we can decompose 36 as a product of _e-primes_ in two different ways:

36 = 2 × 18 = 6 × 6.

Therefore, there is no such thing as unique factorization of even numbers into e-primes.

Your task here is to write a function called `factorizationCount(num)`, which takes in a positive integer and returns the number of ways to decompose that number into a unique product of e-primes. The order in the factorization does not matter; in other words, 2 × 18 and 18 × 2 count as the same factorization of 36, so `factorizationCount(num)` is equal to 2.

Here are some examples:

```javascript
factorizationCount(2) // 1  (2)
factorizationCount(4) // 1  (2 * 2)
factorizationCount(36) // 2 (2 * 18, 6 * 6)
factorizationCount(180) // 3 (2 * 90, 6 * 30, 10 * 18)
factorizationCount(504) // 4 (2 * 2 * 126, 2 * 6 * 42, 2 * 14 * 18, 6 * 6 * 14)
factorizationCount(3) // 0
factorizationCount(2.6) // 0
factorizationCount(-2) // 0
```

Good luck!

(For more on e-primes, check out Joseph Silverman's _A Friendly Introduction to Number Theory_.)
